Fields.DialogueText: Nashville! There you are. You missed the strategy meeting.
Did I? Well, it serves you right for scheduling it during my guitar practice.
Okay, we're going to need to make time for a conversation about priorities - but right now I want to make sure you get briefed on the plan going forward.
Oh, yeah, I'm all over it. We head out and fight something for some reason, and then repeat until they stop fighting back.
That's broadly true, yes, but I think you'll find that the specifics are actually very interesting.
I sincerely doubt that. Come and get me if we have a fight on our hands, but I imagine I won't be able to make it to any future strategy meetings you have.

Fields.MenuText: At least you're honest about not wanting to contribute meaningfully to the fleet.
You have a responsibility to yourself and to your crew to be prepared for what's coming.
How about we don't come and get you, and see how you handle a battle when no one is taking care of you?

Fields.DialogueText: Hey, I contribute to your fleet. If I stop smashing Morganas' skulls in, then a discussion might be in order.
Eh, they'll tell me if there's something I need to know. They're pretty good about that sort of thing.
Psh, I'd do fine. There's not anything those Morganas can do that'll put a dent in me.
I really hope you find a way to quell that overconfidence before it gets you killed, Nashville.
Yeah, yeah, I've heard it all before. Now I think I hear the alarm, so why don't you let me do my thing?
@BATTLE
Nashville, get down from there! You're setting a bad example for the crew!
No, I'm not. None of them could have climbed the conning tower, so it's a moot point.
That's exactly my point! What if one of them tries and falls off? They'll splatter on your deck.
Serves them right for thinking they can do something they can't. People should know their limits.
Are you serious?
Why wouldn't I be, Captain?
Gah, this isn't important right now. But you do need to come down.

Fields.MenuText: We have an engagement soon, and I need you at the ready.
Why don't you go ask the crew if you missed anything important at yet another strategy meeting.
I want you at your station for the foreseeable future. I don't want to have to tell you when the fight is starting.

Fields.DialogueText: All right, Mom, I'll get down. I was getting tired of the view, anyway.
Nah, they'll come and tell me about it. But I might go see if any of them want to play.
That makes zero sense, Captain. My brain would rot if I just sat there like a bump on a log.
*ALARM*
Oh, look, there's the alarm! You think you would have known it was coming if you'd been at the meeting?
What's the point? That's why they invented alarms in the first place.
@BATTLE
Hey, Nashville, is that you playing? You're pretty good.
Pretty good, Captain? Please. I'm the best guitar player you've ever heard.
Well, you certainly have enough time to practice, seeing as you skip every meeting we have.
I know, Captain. Thanks for making them so mind-numbingly lengthy, or I wouldn't be half as proficient as I am now.
Well, at least you're being productive with your time. You could just be off taking naps.
If I wanted a nap, I'd come to the meetings.

Fields.MenuText: You're going miss a piece of very important information eventually, and we'll all pay the price.
As long as the competent members of your crew are in attendance, I suppose it doesn't matter too much what you do.
We're all out here together, Nashville, whatever you might think. I would appreciate you showing it.

Fields.DialogueText: You sound like you're trying to convince me to stop skipping class. Let me tell you up front - you're not going to have much success.
Hey, what's that supposed to mean, Captain? I'm the most competent member of my crew.
Bah, the rest of you are lucky I'm here pulling your weight. Where would you be without me?
We'll talk about that later. There's major Morgana activity to the north, and we're heading to meet them.
What? Why didn't you say so! Battle stations, everyone!
@BATTLE
Hey Nashville, I need you to-
Maybe it is, Captain. Maybe I wanted some water that would remind me of home. Did you even think of that?
I can smell it from here. I thought someone left engine cleaner open in the mess hall.
Anyone worth a damn will get used to it. This'll put hair on your chest and any other body part you care to name.
So, I'm just going to assume that's a big jar of moonshine.
Oh no, Captain. This is the little jar. Maybe sometime I'll show you the big jar.

Fields.MenuText: As long as you don't let that get in the way of your duties, I'm not going to have an issue with it.
You wouldn't happen to be in a sharing mood, would you? I'd be happy with a pull of that.
Does it work as a degreaser? We might have to make do if supplies ever run low.

Fields.DialogueText: I would never let my drinking stop me from fighting, Captain. Perish the thought.
Do you think you can handle this stuff, Captain? It's mighty strong just to go handing out.
You know, I've never actually tried. It does get my motor running fine, though, so I imagine it would work wonders.
Make sure you don't get too far gone, because we have an engagement coming up.
Wish you'd told me sooner. I'd be done with this by now. I hate leaving these unfinished.
@BATTLE
I imagine. That stuff can peel the paint right off the walls.
Now how the hell do you know that, Captain?
What are you drinking? I assume it's not a jar of water.

Fields.MenuText: Just a joke.
You'd be surprised what I get up to when I have shore leave.
Look at the walls, Nashville.

Fields.DialogueText: You're giving it too much credit.
Huh.
Your methods of preparing for battle certainly are… unorthodox, Nashville, but you do always seem to pull through in the end.
Yeah, well, it's a scramble, but war is chaos. Having any warning before battle is a luxury.
Are you serious? We knew about our last fight hours in advance. Sometimes we have days of warning.
Wait, what? I thought we were just rambling around looking to pick a fight.
No! That would be incredibly… well, stupid. Why would you think that was our plan?
Well, I didn't have a lot of information to prove otherwise, did I?
Yes, you did! That's why we have those briefings! What did you think we were doing there?
I figured you just loved to hear yourself talk.

Fields.MenuText: I can't believe you thought we were just bumbling around, waiting to be attacked.
Thank goodness for your crew, or you'd have been wiped out long ago. They must be extremely well prepared.
This is insane, Nashville. You're a warship! You should have a better understanding of how these things work.

Fields.DialogueText: It's worked so far, hasn't it?
I taught them everything they know, of course.
I reckon if I didn't, we wouldn't be having this pointless conversation.
*ALARM*
We'll deal with this later. We have more important things to do.
You're one to talk, Captain Meeting.
@BATTLE
Nashville, I have a question for you. I was reviewing your ship's plans recently, and I noticed something.
Reviewing my plans, Captain? How dare you! That's my privacy you've invaded there.
I'm… sorry? You know that those are available to me at any time, right? Because I'm the captain?
Well, I don't like it. I want you to put those plans back where you found them. I don't want them out where any Tom, Dick, and Harry can take a gander at them.
I didn't know that it would bother you so much. Did you know they were available?
No! I would never have allowed just anyone to come and look at my plans.

Fields.MenuText: You know I'm not just anyone, correct? I do have clearance for these things.
How do you think the maintenance crews repair you? At least a few people have to be able to see your plans.
I'm not in the mood for dealing with your antics right now, Nashville. Your plans are naval property.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't care what clearance you think you have, buddy. My plans are my business.
What? How many people have seen my plans? Why would they do this?
Am I naval property, then? I'm not beholden to anyone!
*ALARM*
There's the alarm. We'll talk about this later. We have a fight on our hands now.
@BATTLE
The Navy's gonna have a fight on their hands. What if I had a file full of X-rays of you lying around?
That's ridiculous. But, now that you mention it, I would be curious.
... You're weird. Why are you weird?
Hey, Nashville, are you feeling any better? I didn't mean to upset you earlier.
I suppose so, Captain, at least a little bit. I'd rather you ask before you peruse my plans, though.
I can do that. I had no idea it would upset you so badly.
I guess it just caught me by surprise.
I suppose it would. Truthfully, it didn't even cross my mind that it would be an issue.
Yeah, well, I imagine thinking about things doesn't exactly come easy to you, does it?

Fields.MenuText: There we go. I knew you'd be back to insulting me soon enough.
I'll have to use that excuse next time I make you upset. Perhaps I can even get some sympathy.
And now I think it's time for the sympathy party to end. Why don't you go get to work somewhere?

Fields.DialogueText: It's refreshingly easy, Captain. I have to thank you for making yourself such an easy target.
It might work on me, Captain. I do have a certain soft spot for the feebleminded.
Work? Eh. I think it's high time for a battle, actually.
*ALARM*
Looks like it's time to get out there and do some damage.
You had me at the part where you stopped talking and I went off to do something interesting.
@BATTLE
Well, good. I'd be more worried if you weren't your usual brash and outspoken self.
Damn straight.
That sounded wonderful, Nashville. How long have you been playing?
Wah! Captain, what are you doing here? How long have you been listening?
Oh, I could hear your guitar from the top deck, so I just wandered down here to listen for myself.
Well, this is my private practice space. I'd prefer it if you didn't barge in here without my permission.
I didn't barge in. You left the door unlocked. I just walked in a few minutes ago.
Well... you still shouldn't have been watching me practice. If I wanted an audience, I'd have been outside.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sorry to have bothered you, Nashville. I'll just be on my way, then.
These are my quarters, you know.
You seem to have a thing for poorly defined lines of privacy. Maybe a list of what you consider to be an invasion would help.

Fields.DialogueText: No, you can stay. I just didn't like looking up and seeing you all of a sudden.
The whole ship is my quarters.
Maybe if you were less of a nosy jerk, a list wouldn't be necessary.
*ALARM*
It looks like we'll have to work this out later.
I suppose so. You got pretty lucky this time.
@BATTLE
Sorry to disappoint you.
Better'n the alternative. I wouldn't have picked an unlucky captain.
Hey, Nashville, I was wondering if I could get your opinion on some tactical plans we're drawing up.
Oh, do tell, Captain. Have you considered sneaking up on the Morganas when they aren't paying attention?
You could watch them for as long as you want, and gather information on their movements.
Uh, yes, actually. That's called reconnaissance. We do that a lot, actually.
See how ahead of the curve I am? You had the right idea coming to me.
Do you actually want to see the plan so you can provide useful insight on the matter?
No, no, I do not. Reading is a bit of a bore, honestly.

Fields.MenuText: Are you serious?
Right, of course. I'm not sure why I thought you might have wanted to give some input.
It's a miracle this ship is still afloat.

Fields.DialogueText: Like a fever. I'm always ready for a scrap with those floating junkyards, but too much preparation makes my trigger finger itch.
Me neither. Go talk to one of the girls who actually likes being bored.
Hey! Watch your mouth.
*ALARM*
All right, let's get to the actual fighting then, shall we?
@BATTLE
Well, would you listen to that? Talk enough nonsense and once in a while you might stumble into my language.
I knocked this time. I hope I'm not interrupting your music-making.
Actually, I was just taking a little break. What do you need, Captain?
Have you ever considered playing your guitar for the crew? I'm sure they would appreciate that sort of thing.
Well, yeah, but I figure they can hear me just fine from down here. The music carries.
Well, yes, but how about a proper concert? The crew could use a break now and again.
I don't see the point, and I'm not sure I'd be interested in doing something like that.

Fields.MenuText: Well now, Nashville. I didn't peg you for a coward.
People like music, and I think the crew's morale would benefit from a concert. Can't you see that?
Oh, don't worry. I'm sure they can get by on radio broadcasts, memories, and the bits of your guitar playing that carry.

Fields.DialogueText: Hey now, I'm not a coward. I just don't feel like showing off. It's not really my thing.
You may have a point there. I suppose I could consider the possibility.
And now you're trying to guilt me? Please. My heart is a fortress.
*ALARM*
My music certainly beats that dadgum alarm.
Maybe. They both carry pretty well, though.
@BATTLE
*KNOCK*
Don't get fresh. I routinely carry all of you through these fights.
Nashville, when I came to talk to you earlier, I had a question I wanted to ask about your layout.
Tread carefully there, Captain. But I suppose I can answer you a question.
It looks like you have a sealed-off section somewhere inside of you, and I was wondering what that was all about.
Don't worry about it, Captain. It's nothing.
It just seems very odd to have a locked section inside a ship. Is this another matter of privacy?
No, Captain. Just forget about it.

Fields.MenuText: Is there some monster conjured up by H.P. Lovecraft roaming those halls?
It's going to be difficult to forget, now that I know something's down there.
Can you appear in there or something? I imagine it's your secret lair now.

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! As if. I never much cared for his work. Besides, if there were we'd be screwed anyway.
That sounds like a personal problem.
I can, but I absolutely will not, under any circumstances.
*ALARM*
We've got a war to fight. There's time to be cryptic later.
That depends entirely on you, Cap.
@BATTLE
Nashville, I have another question for you. It's about your military history. I pulled some of your records…
Digging into my past without my consent, I see. Didn't I warn you about being nosy?
I apologize, but it didn't seem like that big of an issue. Since you don't like to talk tactics, I imagined seeing the tactics you had used in the past might be helpful.
Oh, I don't doubt you thought you had a reason. Doesn't make it a good one.

Fields.MenuText: I'm going to need to do one or the other. So which do you prefer - talking tactics with me, or me digging through your past?
We're going to keep having this argument until one of us breaks, aren't we?
All right, I'm sorry. Now, is there any chance of getting a straight answer out of you?

Fields.DialogueText: Or maybe - and this is going to sound crazy - you could stop being nosy and just let me do my job?
I figure it's possible, but I think we both know I won't be the one who does.
No, I'm too damn peeved at the moment. How about you spend some time thinking about your actions?
All right, all right, we have an engagement coming up soon. I'll just keep watching you fight.
Now that's something everyone can learn from.
@BATTLE
I cannot believe you, Captain. Going behind my back and nosing around is one thing, but this?
You're going to have to be more specific about what has you peeved, or we'll never get anywhere.
You talked to the crew! My crew!
I have people coming up to me and talking about how great it is that I'm going to be playing for them all!
Well, that is very nice to hear. I had no idea you had decided to go forward with that plan.
Come off it, Captain, I know you did this. And now I have to play!

Fields.MenuText: I don't see why you're blaming me for this. I have better things to do than going around starting rumors.
You know there are more people on the ship than me and you, correct? Any one of them could be behind this.
Well, I guess they do want to hear you play. It sounds like there's no reason not to now.

Fields.DialogueText: Sure you do, Captain. Sure you do.
Oh, yeah? I just bet someone else will turn up and claim responsibility.
Yes, congratulations. You've backed me into a corner, Captain.
I'm not sure what you want me to say. Or what you were hoping to get out of this conversation.
*ALARM*
All right, fine. I hear the alarm. But don't think I'll forget this.
@BATTLE
An apology. Maybe a little groveling.
Not in my repertoire. Maybe your constant skipping of meetings will come in handy after all.
Or maybe it won't.
Captain! I need you to grab one of the marines! Preferably one with a flamethrower!
What? What could you possibly need a flamethrower for?
There's a spider in the mess! We need to kill it and make sure it doesn't spread!
How can a spider spread? Also... spiders, really? I would have thought you above that, Nashville.
I'm not terrified of them! I HATE them! That's why I want it to burn!
All right, how about we just get someone to smash it?
Do it soon! I don't want a swarm of these things attacking!

Fields.MenuText: I don't think spiders swarm, Nashville. That's more of a thing for bees or flies.
All right, all right! I'll make sure it's dealt with.
I'm pretty sure spiders don't attack unless you mess with their web, actually.

Fields.DialogueText: The more you yap about technicalities, the easier it is for a spider to crawl in your big mouth!
Good! I don't want it to start colonizing the ship.
I work the same way, Captain. Especially if it shows up in my mess!
*ALARM*
I'll get a maintenance crew on it after the battle.
@BATTLE
Get two. We don't know what that thing's capable of.
Nashville, I have a serious question for you, and I would appreciate a serious answer.
If you're going to talk like that, I'm not sure what I can do for you.
Nashville, before the start of this war, had you ever seen combat?
I don't know what that has to do with anything.
If you wouldn't mind, I would like you to answer the question, Nashville.
Captain, I'm an American ship, commissioned in 1938. What combat do you think I possibly could have seen before the war?

Fields.MenuText: Then where do you get off criticizing strategy and tactics, when you've never actually had to plan a battle?
I guess we're all pretty lucky that you turned out to be all right in a fight, or we'd have been in a lot of trouble.
That's what I figured. You talk like someone who never really had to put effort into a battle before.

Fields.DialogueText: Hey, Captain, I call them like I see them.
Hey now, I was always going to be an excellent fighter. I just never had the chance before now.
And what's that supposed to mean, Captain? I'm a good fighter and I've never let the fleet down.
We'll talk about this more later, but I think you might need a class in the importance of… everything.
*ALARM*
Oh, that sounds riveting. Thank God for the alarm, or the excitement would have me vibrating through my deck.
@BATTLE
All right, Nashville, I just really need to know - what have you done for the military previously?
As befits a lady of my stature, I have been tasked with very important duties.
In fact, I've carried millions of dollars in gold, along with some pretty important people.
Is that why the cargo hold is sealed off? Did you decide to keep some of the gold?
No, of course not. I wasn't allowed to take souvenirs.
So it's still full of the diplomats, then? That's a bit morbid, Nashville.
No, the diplomats are gone too, of course.
You know what this means, don't you?
No, but I'm sure you're more than happy to tell me.

Fields.MenuText: You're nothing but an upgunned, glorified cargo ship.
You're the most secure luxury cruise ship in American history.
If we ever have to carry anything or anyone, I'm sticking them with you.

Fields.DialogueText: And you're a jumped-up nobody with delusions of admiralty. Why don't you leave insults to the professionals?
Well, I certainly blow the Lusitania out of the water.
Oh, no. Not again. I don't want to spend the rest of my life schlepping folk no one else wants.
*ALARM*
I can hear the alarm, so let's get back to what you're good at.
@BATTLE
Damn near everything, Captain. Be specific or I'll start to think you just like giving orders.
Nashville, you know I'm going to keep pestering you until you tell me. What is wrong with the sealed cargo hold?
All right, fine, Captain, You broke me. It's spiders.
Really? You let a few spiders dictate which parts of your ship are accessible?
Try a few thousand. Someone sold the quartermaster some suspect fruit when we were in Brazil.
A few days later, the spiders erupted. We had to beat them back with flamethrowers and seal the hatch.
Really? That's insane! At least the hold should be tight enough to keep them trapped, right?
So far, I think. I still don't like seeing spiders on the rest of the ship, but I haven't seen any of those.

Fields.MenuText: I feel a little bad for making fun of you, now that I know you actually have a reason to hate them.
I can't believe you've just let the infestation sit there for years without doing anything about it.
We really need to figure out a way to get rid of them. I don't like knowing they're there.

Fields.DialogueText: It's all right. No one expected you to actually stop and think about anything for two seconds.
Years? It started a month before the fleet was formed. I'd say we've been a bit busy.
You don't like it? I can almost feel them. But what are we going to do about it when we have bigger problems?
All right, I'll be thinking about what you said, but we have an engagement coming up. Let's get ready.
Ugh! Damn it, now I'm thinking about them again. This is your fault, Captain.
Well, we have an engagement coming up. Let's get ready.
@BATTLE
Hey, Nashville, what's the hurry? It seems like you and the crew are headed somewhere fast.
Well, I told the crew to meet me in the mess, because I thought I might put on a little show for them.
What are you... Oh! You're playing a show for them, are you?
That's my plan, yes. You're welcome to come sit in on it if you'd like.
I don't have much in the way of accompaniment, but I'm the best guitar player you've ever met, so that'll be something.
Well, I'm certainly excited to hear it. Just a reminder, though, we are currently moving towards hostile forces.
Then I'll just go ahead and get the men all riled up for a nice big fight.

Fields.MenuText: That does sound nice. Boosting the men's spirits is a laudable undertaking.
A quick show does sound like just the thing to make everyone feel better about where we're going.
Just don't get them so rowdy they forget who the enemy is.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm just giving in to popular demand, Captain. I can't help it if my crew loves me.
If you think "accept your fate" is a good theme for a concert, you put it on and let me know how that goes.
I'm not liable to start a riot in the mess hall, Captain. Unless you keep me talking for too long and I'm late.
Fair enough. We've got an hour or so before we need to go to battle stations, so go ahead and play.
Just don't interrupt me with that alarm, or the Morganas will have to fight me for your soul or whatever.
@BATTLE
Hello, Nashville! Congratulations on the reception! Word of your concert is already filtering through the fleet.
Well, of course it is. I'm the best guitar player anyone has ever met.
That brings me to another point, interestingly enough. The rest of the fleet would like to see you.
How do you mean, Captain? I'm not exactly easy to miss out here.
I've received multiple requests that other crews be allowed to attend one of your concerts.
Well, I don't really have an issue with that. Now that I've got a bit of a taste for it, I might as well share my gifts.

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad you agree, because with the way your crew has been talking you up, I'd hate to tell the rest of the fleet no.
Does that mean you're past that little bout of stage fright?
I'm happy to know you're excited about it. I might even look into adding a few more acts.

Fields.DialogueText: It's a good thing you don't have to, then. I'd certainly never want you to do something difficult.
I never had stage fright. If you're going to spread rumors, at least spread fun ones.
I wouldn't go that far, but I'll definitely look into filling out my band a little bit.
I will be sure to spread the good news around the fleet.
*ALARM*
Well, there's the alarm. The good news can wait for a while longer.
@BATTLE
Here's a puzzle for you, Captain. Where do we put the concert so that I don't have to get rid of my own crew?
What do you mean get rid of your crew, exactly? I thought you were rather attached to them.
Of course I am, Captain, and that's the point. There's only so much space in my hull.
I'd rather not have to shuttle my actual crew off to make room for the other spectators.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe we could play off the deck, and set up some speakers to carry over the water.
Perhaps we could play over the radio and see if everyone can tune in?
Maybe we'll just bring them in a few at a time?

Fields.DialogueText: If you can find the speakers for it, you've got better places to be than a war. Among other reasons.
That will ruin the sound quality, and we want people to actually enjoy this concert.
Preferably, we'd be able to play for enough people at a time that I wouldn't die of old age before we finished.
All right, well, we'll have to put some effort into figuring out where we can have a show.
On the plus side, I found some fellows among the crew who want to help fill out my act.
Really? I had no idea we had a band waiting in the wings.
*ALARM*
Eh, they know what they signed up for. Try it with me and we'd have words.
@BATTLE
You didn't dig into their backgrounds? That doesn't seem like you.
Yeah, yeah. I don't breach people's privacy unless it pertains to our survival.
They seem to have resulted in a concert.
They're gonna result in a lot more if you don't haul ass to the bridge.
Huh. How many?
We have more musicians than instruments, actually. Whatever - we'll figure something out.
So, I had a thought about where to hold that concert, but I don't think you're going to like it.
I'm pretty sure I know what you're going to say, and I really don't want you to say it.
We can clear out the cargo hold.
Or… we could clear out a different cargo area.
What if I dumped off all of my munitions? That seems like a reasonable plan to me.
You and I have different definitions of the word reasonable.
What if I rammed the Morganas, and then when the hull cracked open, the spiders would spill all over them?

Fields.MenuText: You need to take the dressing off this wound, or it's never going to heal properly.
I'm not sure Morganas are as terrified of spiders as you are. That may be worth exploring, though.
If it makes you feel better, you aren't the one who has to deal with the spiders. We have crew for that.

Fields.DialogueText: Who taught you medicine? The dressing is what helps the wound heal properly. Keeps out the spiders, too.
See? We need to explore different types of warfare if at all possible.
The callous way you throw your crew to the ravages of spiders has been noted, Captain.
@BATTLE
While we're at it, let's make it a benefit concert.
You, feeling charitable? This is new. What for?
Victims of chronic spiderism.
Am I in the presence of their queen?
You've got a capable crew. We'll get some of them on this at the earliest opportunity.
Keep it up and I'll show you why we got rid of our royalty.
*ALARM*
All right, Marines, time to earn your keep. Get in there and sort those little devils out for me.
Are you sure we needed the big guns for this?
They're about to cut the door open, so why don't you keep an eye on it and tell me?
Of course. I still think you're…
Holy hellspit! KILL 'EM WITH FIRE!
See!? That's what my boys are here for, Captain. And you thought there wouldn't be a need.
How did they get so big? And so numerous? Why are there still so many in there?
As long as they don't make it past the door, I'm okay. And we have damage control teams standing by.

Fields.MenuText: I'll be honest, before today I never thought I'd see a need for using flamethrowers aboard a ship.
Marines were a good idea. Just a damn good idea.
I just don't want to think about what they were eating in there. Some of them look way too smart.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm always happy to teach you something new, Captain. A day you don't learn something is a day wasted.
Oh, I would feel downright naked without them. They're here to solve problems.
We'll pick through the ruins later, after the boys are through. I want everything in there burned twice.
Let's get this under control. We're in hostile waters.
@BATTLE
All waters are hostile waters with those things skittering around.
Well, it looks like we cleared out the storage area pretty well. What do you think?
I think you didn't do anything to clean this area out, and you're taking credit for the work of others.
But yes, I think we can have a nice little concert in here. I bet we could fit several dozen people inside.
Plus, we could use this as an actual storage area once again once the concert is over.
More space is always good. But if the concerts are a hit, it would be a shame to fill it up again.
Is that a wistful eye I see? Do you think you'd like to continue doing these concerts?
How about we see how the first one goes. Then maybe I'll think about the future.

Fields.MenuText: We'll make sure the first one goes off without a hitch.
Are you sure you're going to put on a good enough show that people will want a second helping?
I think the biggest question is how the acoustics will fare in here. It is a big metal box, after all.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad to have your support, Cap.
Oh please. You've been trying to bait me into playing again since the first time you heard me.
I'll get that tested out soon, but these are sailors. They're used to things being rough.
*ALARM*
I hear the alarm. C'mon, Nashville.
You've got it, Cap. I think this room still needs to breathe for a while.
@BATTLE
It's beginning to look like a real concert hall down there. I do really like the tiered seating.
You can thank maintenance and the marines for that. They're both pretty good at scrounging.
Did they paint it up as well, or is that caked-on spider smoke on the walls?
They painted it after they washed the walls down. I asked them to create a subdued atmosphere.
Well, they've done an excellent job. I talked to the other ships, and we'll be all set soon.
That sounds perfect. I'm really excited for this, I don't mind saying.
I've got the rest of the band practicing, although I'm not sure they're going to be out there the whole time.

Fields.MenuText: Looking forward to being your own solo act again so soon? And after all the effort your band put in.
I'm glad you're ready for this. I think you've put more planning into this than any of the battles we've fought so far.
I look forward to seeing you in concert, Nashville. But don't let that go to your head.

Fields.DialogueText: It's not like that. I just think there are a few different ways we can come at this, and I want to try them all before I settle.
All you have to do in a fight is blow stuff up. There's not much call for it to sound pretty.
I wouldn't dream of it, Captain. You're far too easily impressed for me to care.
We'll have to drive off the local Morganas first. That should buy us enough time for the concert. Then things can go back to normal.
What do you mean?
@BATTLE
I thought you didn't want to be in the spotlight.
Well, sure. Not with you dragging me into it.
What changed?
The stage does strange things to a girl, Cap. You get to show off a completely new side of yourself. Sometimes it doesn't even seem new, on account of how long you've lived with it.
It's the world giving you the words to a song you've been singing your whole life, and you didn't even know there were any.
But the more natural it comes to you, the bigger the surprise the first time that curtain comes up and you put faces to those cheers you've been wondering powerful hard about.
*ALARM*
But mostly, I realized I could rub all those missed strategy meetings in your face and get everyone else to sing along.
Maybe you never needed them.
What can I say? I'm an improv girl.
So, Captain, be honest, how do you think I did?
I think the packed house and the standing ovation speak for themselves.
I didn't ask you what the crowd thought. I asked what you thought.
Are you sure you want to know? What if I hated it?
Then you're just as dull as I always suspected you were. Now stop playing coy and tell me the truth.
You were great. And, more to the point, everyone loved listening, and you really brought the fleet together.
You're really adept at telling me what other people think, no matter how directly I ask you for your opinion.
If I didn't know any better, Captain, I'd say you were embarrassed to tell me your true thoughts.
But that can't be right. The captain of the fleet is far too brave to let something like fear get in their way.

Fields.MenuText: You're a wonderful musician, Nashville, and I'll see to it you're a trained soldier by the end of this war as well.
Nashville, you are a treasure to the fleet. There, are you happy?

Fields.DialogueText: Takes two to train, Cap. One to train and one to listen.
Look at you, Captain. Getting all sentimental.
I'm not the only one who can bait someone into something.
Reckon I'd better start reeling.
That doesn't make sense.
Shows which one you are. Don't worry. You've caught my interest.
